children.name: to answer a teacher, parent etc in a rude way
talk back
children.definition: answer back/ to answer sb rudely, especially a teacher, parent etc when they criticize you or tell you to do sth: trả treo, cãi lại
examples: ▪ Don’t talk back. It’s rude.

children.name: answer sb back: trả treo ai, cãi lại ai
examples: ▪ We were all scared of Mr Williams, but here was a girl who actually answered him back.

children.name: talk back to sb: trả treo, cãi lại ai
examples: ▪ Don’t talk back to your mother like that!

children.name: back talk
children.definition: alsoback chatBritish  rude remarks that sb makes when they answer their teacher, parent etc: câu trả lời xấc láo, trả treo, cãi lại
examples: ▪ I don’t want any excuses, complaints, or back talk.
▪ Any more of your back chat and you’ll have to stay behind after school.

children.name: when sb is rude to teachers, parents etc
disrespectful
children.definition: rude, especially towards sb you should respect, for example your parents or sb in authority: không tôn trọng, bất lịch sự
examples: ▪ A letter from the school arrived, saying that Joey had been both disobedient and disrespectful.
disrespect[T] to offend or behave in a rude way towards sb: thô lỗ, thiếu tôn trọng
The ambassador said it had not been his intention to disrespect the US government.
Some students do feel that teachers disrespect them.

children.name: disrespectful to
examples: ▪ In Chinese culture, it is considered disrespectful to both the living and the dead to live near a burial ground.

children.name: disrespectful aboutBritish
examples: ▪ He thought I was being disrespectful about his country.

children.name: it is disrespectful (for sb) to do sth
examples: ▪ Some older people think it disrespectful for strangers to call them by their first name.

children.name: cheeky
children.definition: UK/ sassyUS behaving in a way that is a little rude, especially when this is amusing or annoying – used especially about children : hỗn, xấc

children.name: I don’t like teaching that class - the kids are all so cheeky
examples: What do you mean, I’m fat? You cheeky devil!
She's got such a cheeky grin.
Don't be so cheeky!

children.name: She was sassy and smart, and all the kids liked her
examples: Becky was a sassy, rambunctious New York girl he’d met when visiting his aunt.
a sassy brat.

children.name: impertinent
children.definition: formal rude and showing no respect for sb in authority, especially by saying things or asking questions about sth that it is not your right to know or discuss: xấc xược, xấc náo
examples: ▪ By now he had gotten used to reporters’ impertinent questions about his private life.
▪ Could I ask how old you are, or would that be impertinent?

children.name: impudent
children.definition: formal sb who is impudent, especially a child or young person, is rude and has no respect for people who are older or more important: thô lỗ, thiếu tôn trọng
examples: ▪ She didn’t think the child’s questions were endearing -- just impudent.
▪ On the cover was a picture on an impudent boy sticking out his tongue.
impudence[U]
▪ He looked at me with a mixture of impudence and hostility.Anh ấy nhìn tôi với sự pha tạp và thù địch

children.name: insolent
children.definition: formal very rude to sb in authority and appearing to have no respect for them, especially by not doing what they tell you to do :thô lỗ, thiếu tôn trọng
examples: Although she didn’t actually say anything offensive, her expression was sulky, insolent, and hostile.
The girl’s only response was an insolent stare.|Don’t be so insolent!

children.name: irreverent
children.definition: showing a lack of respect for someone or something who people are supposed to respect – used especially about comedy programmes and newspaper articles : thiếu tôn trọng
examples: an irreverent look at the week’s events
his irreverent sense of humour

children.name: impolite
children.definition: not following the rules of accepted social behaviour, especially when someone does this without realizing it - use this especially about the things that people do or say, rather than about people themselves.Impolitesounds rather formal ::không lịch sự
examples: In Senegal it is considered impolite if you do not share your food.
it is impolite to do sth
It is impolite and inconsiderate for people to drop in uninvited

children.name: abrasive
children.definition: seeming rude or unkind because you say what you think very directly, so that people are annoyed or offended:thô lỗ

children.name: Harris was abrasive and arrogant
examples: Anson’s abrasive personality has landed her in trouble many times in the past.

children.name: bad-mannered
children.definition: / ill-manneredespecially writtenbehaving in a rude and unpleasant way, especially because of never having been taught how to be polite :cư xử thô lỗ
examples: Her children are incredibly bad-mannered -- she should be more strict with them.
Ill-mannered movie-goers talked and took cell phone calls during the picture.

children.name: As soon as some English people go abroad, they seem to change into bad-mannered, insensitive oafs
examples: Ill-mannered movie-goers talked throughout the entire picture.|It was very bad-mannered.

children.name: discourteous
children.definition: formal not behaving in a polite way.Discourteoussounds very formal and is often used when talking about being careful not to upset someone’s feelings - use this especially about people’s remarks or behaviour: không lịch thiệp
examples: It would have seemed discourteous to refuse his offer.
It would seem discourteous to refuse her offer.

children.name: discourteous to
examples: He claimed that the officer had been discourteous to him.
He did not wish to appear discourteous towards his host.

children.name: unpleasant
children.definition: to deliberately behave in a rude and unfriendly way towards sb:gây khó chịu

children.name: be unpleasant
examples: He can be very unpleasant when he’s in a bad mood.
It isn’t necessary to be that unpleasant, Mike.

children.name: be unpleasant to
examples: She was shocked at how unpleasant the children were to their mother.

children.name: loutish
children.definition: rude, loud, and unpleasant - use this especially about people’s behaviour: thô lỗ
examples: The behaviour of some politicians in debates is simply loutish and intimidating.
They considered my boyfriend to be loutish and a bit stupid.'
loutish behaviour

children.name: not polite
children.definition: not following the rules of accepted social behaviour, especially when someone does this without realizing it - use this especially about the things that people do or say, rather than about people themselves:không lịch sự
examples: You weren’t very polite to her.
it is not polite to do sth
I was tired, but I thought it might not be polite to leave so early

children.name: rude
children.definition: b who isrudeupsets or offends people by not following the rules of good social behaviour and not considering other people’s feelings:thô lỗ, bất lịch sự
examples: ▪ What a rude man! He just ignored me when I said ‘Good morning’.
▪ I don’t mean to be rude, but could you tell your children to keep quiet?
▪ He’s one of the rudest people I’ve ever met.
rude to
▪ I know you’re upset, but there’s no need to be rude to your mother.Tôi biết bạn đang buồn, nhưng không cần phải thô lỗ với mẹ bạn.
rude about
▪ Are you being rude about my cooking?
it is rude to do sth
▪ It’s rude to interrupt people when they are speaking. Khó mà làm gián đoạn mọi người khi họ nói chuyện.
it is rude of sb to do sth
▪ I thought it was very rude of her not to answer my letter
rudely[adv] C1
▪ Blair rudely pushed his way to the front of the line.
rudeness[U]
▪ Please forgive me for my rudeness the other day.

children.name: words for describing behaviour, remarks etc that offend people
offensive
children.definition: speaking or behaving in a way that is likely to upset or offend sb : gây xúc phạm
examples: His remarks are offensive to African-Americans.
offensively[adv]
As usual, he got drunk and behaved offensively towards the guests.

children.name: offensive language
examples: Throughout the football game a small section of the crowd was chanting offensive slogans.
The BBC received a number of complaints about the offensive remarks made during the interview.
deeply offensivevery offensive:
These pornographic magazines are deeply offensive to women.

children.name: offensive to
examples: Your comments are offensive to all Jews.

children.name: insulting
children.definition: behaviour, remarks etc that are insulting offend sb a lot because they show a lack of respect for them or for their ability, honesty etc:
examples: ▪ It’s insulting when people assume I must be a racist because I’m from the South.
deeply insultingvery insulting
▪ I find your criticism deeply insulting.
insulting to
▪ advice that is extremely insulting to unemployed people

children.name: be an insult to
children.definition: /biː ən ˈɪnsʌlt tuː/  to offend a particular person or group of people by showing little respect for their intelligence, ability, beliefs etc:xúc phạm ai đó
examples: ▪ Leaders described the mosque’s destruction as an insult to Muslims.
be an insult to sb’s intelligence/ability etc:
▪ The lesson was awful. It was an insult to our intelligence.
▪ If I didn’t finish this meal it would be an insult to your superb cooking.

children.name: objectionable
children.definition: sth that is objectionable is likely to offend people because it is morally unacceptable or very unpleasant: chướng tai, gai mắt
examples: ▪ I thought the bedroom scenes were pretty objectionable and unnecessary.
▪ Our goal is to get rid of many of the objectionable features of capitalism.

children.name: highly/deeply objectionable
examples: ▪ I find it highly objectionable to have to sit near people who are smoking.

children.name: yob
children.definition: /jɒbǁjɑːb/  British a young man who is rude, noisy, and sometimes violent:người đàn bà thô tục, bạo lực
examples: ▪ A dozen yobs stood outside the pubMọt tá thanh niên đứng bên ngoài quán rượu.
▪ Residents complained that yobs had been vandalizing their gardens.

children.name: yob culture: văn hóa bạo lực
examples: TV programmes, films, and other forms of entertainment that involve rudeness and unintelligent behaviour.
▪ Our TV screens have been taken over by so-called yob culture.

children.name: jerk
children.definition: /dʒɜːʳk/  especially American an annoying person who behaves in a stupid way, for example by behaving in a rude and unpleasant way:cư xử thô lỗ
examples: ▪ Ignore him. He’s just a jerk.Bỏ qua cho anh ta. Anh ta cũng chỉ là một tên thô lỗ.
▪ He’s an unprofessional jerk who’s always pestering the women in the office.

children.name: real/total jerk: cư xử thô lỗ
examples: ▪ Her husband was being a real jerk about the divorce.Chồng cô thực sự là một kẻ điên rồ thực sự về li hôn.

children.name: lout
children.definition: a man or boy who behaves in a rude and violent way:
examples: A few foul-mouthed louts in the crowd were shouting racist abuse.
Only a lout would treat a woman that way..

children.name: lager loutsBritish young men who drink too much beer and behave in rude or violent way
examples: We stood at the bar being jostled by some thick-necked lager louts.

children.name: to do sth rude without seeming embarrassed
have the nerve
children.definition: / have the cheekUK  if sb has the nerve to do sth, they do sth that you think is so rude that you are surprised they did it: có gan

children.name: have the nerve to do sth
examples: ▪ He forgot our anniversary and then had the nerve to ask what I got him when I reminded him about it.

children.name: have a nerve/cheekUK/have (some) nerve
examples: ▪ He’s got a cheek, coming back at midnight and then expecting me to cook his dinner.

children.name: what a nerve/cheekUK/what a nerveUS
examples: ▪ What a nerve! I hope you didn’t give him the money!

children.name: have the gall to do sth
children.definition: if sb has the gall to do sth, they do sth that you think is very rude and unreasonable: dám trơ tráo làm gì, "mật"
examples: ▪ I can’t believe he had the gall to ask you for money.

children.name: ▪ Ruth was always on the phone and yet she had the gall to tell me off for making one call
take the liberty of
children.definition: doingsthformal to do sth that will have an effect on sb else, without asking their permission
examples: I took the liberty of booking theatre seats for us.
